title: How to Store Children's Clothing for a Younger Child to Wear in the Future

steps.headline: Get some big, heavy plastic storage boxes, such as those made by Rubbermaid.
steps.description: They can be clear if you are storing the clothing in a dark place like an attic or a basement; otherwise they should be dark and opaque to protect clothes from fading.

steps.headline: Get all the clothes that you want to store absolutely CLEAN AND DRY.
steps.description: Wash thoroughly and run through the dryer till bone dry, and have the dry-cleanable ones dry-cleaned.

steps.headline: Moths and bugs that eat holes in clothes are not actually interested in eating the fabric; they want the spilled food or other stains on there.
steps.description: By cleaning the clothes you are removing temptations for them, as well as getting rid of any eggs that are on there.

steps.headline: If there are torn seams or missing buttons, fix them.
Sort the clothes by size, according to how much of them you have and how different they are.
steps.description: Everyone's sorting will look different -- some people might just have piles of "young boys" and "older girls" clothing -- others might have a pile labeled "boys 12 months," "boys 18 months," etc.

steps.headline: Get rid of what you can.
steps.description: Most clothes you buy these days aren't intended to last for generations, and really, who wants to wear old underwear? Don't kid yourself by saving socks and underwear unless you are the really, REALLY thrifty type. Make them into rags (old socks on your hands are great for polishing wood and silver.)

steps.headline: If you have a really, really special item like a woolen suit or a taffeta dress, take it to the cleaners and have them pack it in a box for you.
For the regular clothes, make as many piles as you need and figure out how many piles can fit in each box.
The best way to store clothes is by rolling them up tight.
steps.description: This keeps deep creases from happening and makes the best use of your space. So lay out a shirt, fold it vertically (from neck to waist), and roll it tight from the bottom. Ditto pants -- lay them out, fold vertically, and roll it tight.

steps.headline: Do not use mothballs -- they are very toxic for humans and the smell never really goes away.
steps.description: If you have cleaned the clothes thoroughly bugs should not be an issue. If you want to put SOMETHING in with the clothes, you can put in cedar blocks or balls, but be aware that the oils from these can stain clothes. Same with dryer sheets.

steps.headline: Add the clothes to the box.
steps.description: If you are putting more than one sorting bundle in a box, you may want to tie the bundles separately with string. Put a masking tape label on the string.

steps.headline: Store bigger, heavier items on the bottom, like big sweaters and pants.
steps.description: Poufy skirts and dresses should go on the top.

steps.headline: LABEL THE BOXES AS YOU GO.
Put on lids and store away.
steps.description: If you have to stack, do it so the youngest clothing is on top and you can work your way to the bottom of the stack through the years.

text: Get some big, heavy plastic storage boxes, such as those made by Rubbermaid. They can be clear if you are storing the clothing in a dark place like an attic or a basement; otherwise they should be dark and opaque to protect clothes from fading. Get all the clothes that you want to store absolutely CLEAN AND DRY. Wash thoroughly and run through the dryer till bone dry, and have the dry-cleanable ones dry-cleaned. Moths and bugs that eat holes in clothes are not actually interested in eating the fabric; they want the spilled food or other stains on there. By cleaning the clothes you are removing temptations for them, as well as getting rid of any eggs that are on there. If there are torn seams or missing buttons, fix them.  Sort the clothes by size, according to how much of them you have and how different they are. Everyone's sorting will look different -- some people might just have piles of "young boys" and "older girls" clothing -- others might have a pile labeled "boys 12 months," "boys 18 months," etc. Get rid of what you can. Most clothes you buy these days aren't intended to last for generations, and really, who wants to wear old underwear? Don't kid yourself by saving socks and underwear unless you are the really, REALLY thrifty type. Make them into rags (old socks on your hands are great for polishing wood and silver.) If you have a really, really special item like a woolen suit or a taffeta dress, take it to the cleaners and have them pack it in a box for you.  For the regular clothes, make as many piles as you need and figure out how many piles can fit in each box.  The best way to store clothes is by rolling them up tight. This keeps deep creases from happening and makes the best use of your space. So lay out a shirt, fold it vertically (from neck to waist), and roll it tight from the bottom. Ditto pants -- lay them out, fold vertically, and roll it tight. Do not use mothballs -- they are very toxic for humans and the smell never really goes away. If you have cleaned the clothes thoroughly bugs should not be an issue. If you want to put SOMETHING in with the clothes, you can put in cedar blocks or balls, but be aware that the oils from these can stain clothes. Same with dryer sheets. Add the clothes to the box. If you are putting more than one sorting bundle in a box, you may want to tie the bundles separately with string. Put a masking tape label on the string. Store bigger, heavier items on the bottom, like big sweaters and pants. Poufy skirts and dresses should go on the top. LABEL THE BOXES AS YOU GO. "Boys - 2-3 years"  "Girls - 4-6x" Put on lids and store away. If you have to stack, do it so the youngest clothing is on top and you can work your way to the bottom of the stack through the years.
